subtitle: New Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello and welcome, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I want to remember one of the most inspirational
and controversial figures in the field of
parapsychology, a man who influenced me at the very start of my work in this field when I was still a
graduate student at Berkeley. I'm talking about Andrija
Puharich [1918-1995].
Puharich first came to my attention
when I moved to California in 1969
and he had written a book about the sacred mushroom,
the Amanita Muscaria mushroom, which is a
psychedelic mushroom. He reported having discovered them growing near a property he had in Maine,
in the state of Maine,
and a number of very interesting coincidences that seem to occur around the
use of that mushroom and
its historical and mystical
significance. I learned about this from friends when I first moved to California.
I recall at the time my roommate Peter Hartman, who is another very interesting story
I may tell some day about Peter, shared with me his
reflections on having met someone who bought the book The Sacred Mushroom and within
a few days of having purchased the book discovered the same Amanita Muscaria mushrooms growing
on his own property. So, from the very beginning Puharich had this
reputation as being something of a magician,
a magical person, a magic man.
He was also well known in the early years for having written the book Beyond Telepathy,
it’s actually one of the best books about telepathy to my knowledge ever written.
He had a very simple theory which is that telepathic
transmission occurs when we are emotionally
aroused, I believe he would say in an
adrenergic state. Now, Puharich was a professor of surgery at New York University, a very esteemed
doctor with I think fifty patents to his name.
So, telepathic
transmission occurs in this aroused state, telepathic reception occurs in a relaxed state,
he called that the cholinergic state.
I’m gonna link right now to one of my interviews with Charlie Tart, who was one of my professors
at Berkeley. I think he talks about his sixty years of parapsychology,
he’s still way ahead of me
in that regard
but he got his start working with Andrija Puharich. One of Andrijas other early
experiments had to do with the use of the Faraday cage for
enhancing
psychic abilities and Charlie was able to replicate that work, so
at the scientific level Puharich was quite a pioneer. In 1973,
I moved into the Institute for the Study of Consciousness
in Berkeley at the invitation of the founder Arthur Young, the inventor of the Bell helicopter.
I learned from Arthur, who was seventy years old at the time, I was in my early twenties still,
that he had worked with Andrija Puharich as well
in the state of Maine. Puharich had set up the Round Table
Foundation and he was working with a trance medium who produced
seances, well they were like seances or perhaps more like channelling today. Through those channelings
Puharich came to
establish communication with an entity known as The Nine. Well,
maybe you could say a group of entities, that was a little bit unclear, but The Nine were supposedly associated with the
“Galactic Confederation” and UFO phenomena,
so Puharich already had a great interest in that. Arthur Young who became my mentor and a very
inspirational figure, a brilliant cosmologist,
developed his deep profound interest in UFOs at that time.
Puharich seemed to show up just about everywhere.
For example, in the famous book, a sociological book written in the 1950s
by Leon Festinger, it's a book about a UFO cult in Minnesota,
the name of the book is When Prophecy Fails. I
have much more to say about that book, it might be a very interesting discussion for a future “In Presence”
monologue because the book itself, I think, is a failed prophecy,
but that's another long story.
The interesting thing I want to mention is this UFO cult in Minnesota also had interactions
with doctor Andrija Puharich. I just mention that in passing.
I first met Andrija, or I first heard him speak in about
1971-ish, when there was an organization in the San Francisco Bay Area that
only lasted a few years, it was called the Academy of
Parapsychology and Medicine. They hosted a large symposium at
De Anza College,
on the peninsula in the Bay Area. Andrija was one of the speakers
there and at that time he reported on his discovery
of Arigo, the surgeon with the rusty knife, one of the very first examples of psychic surgery. Puharich
said that even as a medical doctor he let Arigo operate on him.
He took out his rusty knife and removed a cyst
from Puharich’s arm, as I recall. This whole episode incidentally is written up in a book by
John G. Fuller called Arigo: Surgeon of the Rusty Knife.
A few years later
I was already working at KPFA radio in Berkeley
in 1972-ish
as I recall, 1973? I think it was ‘72.
I sponsored a big conference on the Berkeley campus, Zellerbach Auditorium,
we had thousands of people. Well, I think the auditorium held 1800 and it was pretty
near packed. I invited Puharich to be one of my speakers. It was at that event
which attracted a lot of news because he made his first announcement about his
discovery of the Israeli psychic Uri Geller. I had Puharich delivering
seminars in Berkeley to students at the time about his work. I, at the time, was also
head of a small
program on the Berkeley campus called the Health Information Program
where Puharich came and lectured. So,
all of this was going on. We later brought Uri Geller to the
Berkeley campus where various members of the Physics Department and other professors had a chance to witness
first hand some of his
demonstrations. I know every time I talk about Uri Geller the skeptics crawl out of the closet and say, “He didn't perform on Johnny Carson.”
I'm not even going to bother to address that. So what?
That's my response to that.
He didn't perform on one occasion, that's true of just about every psychic. But Puharich wrote the book
Uri and in it he describes in great length,
Uri’s communications with
what appeared to be UFO entities and
described as well their travels together in Israel and the UFOs they observed there
at the time. I happened to try and track all of that down,
much of it is all written up in my first book, The Roots of Consciousness,
published in 1975. Let me say a little more about Andrija Puharich.
One of the other great psychics he discovered was Peter Hurkos,
a Dutch psychic who was well known for working with the police, solving crimes and also
working with researchers
and doing good research. I learned recently doing a little background
investigation for this monologue that Puharich actually appeared on the Perry Mason Show,
it's a courtroom drama show in which he played himself talking about
exposing fake mediums. Puharich in fact did, he went to
I believe it was Camp Chesterfield, a spiritualist
camp spoken of highly by some of my guests.
But in any case, Puharich apparently discovered that they were faking
ectoplasm by
swallowing cheese cloth and then producing it out of their mouth,
that sort of thing. So, he had exposed frauds
as well, at least he believed that he had and I think most people were inclined to believe that.
Looking back I wonder
actually if that was the case because I know,
it's really one of the great paradoxes that sometimes authentic phenomenon
of a spiritualist nature or phenomenon that really cannot, if you look in detail, cannot be explained away
but as soon as you see the photographs they look as phony as you can imagine, too phony, really.
But that's another story.
There's much more that could be said about Andrija Puharich,
he continued after he and Uri had sort of a parting of the ways. I think Uri Geller,
who I still regard as a friend, did not wish to be associated with all of the UFO stories and trance mediumship
and things that Puharich was working with. Uri wanted to be on his own, to be independent of
Puharich, not that he ever denied any of the claims made about Puharich in that regard. But Puharich continued
working with other mediums. As I recall a medium named Joyce Petschek
went into a trance, was receiving
communications from The Nine, that same group of entities.
He was getting funding from a wealthy British financier as I recall, travelling around the world
going to different airports to meditate in different countries for world
peace. He had a watch apparently that was
synchronized and he had to be in certain airports at particular moments in time in order to produce these meditations.
Well, he went through a few marriages
back in those days as well. As I recall his house got burned down. He had a house in Ossining, New York,
near another friend of mine who lived there just north of New York City.
His house got burned down, I think he thought maybe the CIA was after him.
He died in North Carolina in 1995.
He was living on the estate of Joshua Reynolds as I recall, the tobacco heir. My friend
Elizabeth Rauscher,
who's been interviewed on this channel several times, was with him at the time of his death.
They were all living there on the Reynolds estate together.
She explained it to me, he practically died in her arms.
I guess it was sort of a tragic death at the time. They were all sort of
dislocated, you know, living on this estate. They had
all of these people who had
lost their homes basically, lost their own places to live. And then
I believe when Joshua Reynolds died the
attorney managing
the Reynolds estate asked them all to leave, which is about the time I believe when Puharich himself died.
Elizabeth, who is a dear friend of mine
passed away a few years ago as well, so we're talking about a lost generation.
But I can say this, Puharich was a big inspiration to me
and a supporter of my work. When I was just a graduate student
he gave me a copy of his book Uri and inscribed it
in a beautiful way. He said he knew I had a glorious career ahead of me.
Maybe, maybe he was right because I have to say, I do feel like
I'm so blessed to be able to do what Joseph Campbell
has recommended to the viewers of the original Thinking Allowed series, follow your passion.
And I can say this about Andrija, he did, he followed his passion.
There's much more that could be said about him. He worked with military intelligence,
he was involved in some of the early LSD
experiments, I think sponsored by military intelligence.
They were very interested in his sacred mushroom work as a matter of fact, back in the 1950s.
So, he was a colorful figure,
a controversial figure. He was never really considered a...
In parapsychology I think
many people, and let's say the J. B. Rhine clique at Duke University, viewed him as kind of
a wild... a loose cannon perhaps might be the best way to put it. I suppose you have to say he was. But,
I think of him very, very fondly.
I happened to notice that his son
Andy is working on a documentary about his life.
You will read about Andrija in
various books. He seems to pop up just about everywhere.
Well, let me close by asking you this question.
To what extent are you following your passion?
Thank you for being with me.
